segments.text: Okay, this is just a sound check.
Bob, say something.
Hello, my name is Bob.
How many people check this door here?
Probably like 100.
I don't know why they can't have it open.
Okay, this is Ron Shorn, and I'm interviewing Bob Havlin at the American Astronomical Society Berkeley meeting on June 6, 1993.
So, Bob, for the record, what's your full name?
Robert James Havlin.
How do you spell that?
H-A-V-L-E-N.
Where were you born?
Utica, New York.
And when?
A date?
Oh yeah, September 16.
How'd you get interested in astronomy in the first place?
I think it was a Boy Scout project or a science fair project when I was in the sixth or seventh grade.
I had to draw some maps of the night sky and find north.
That started my desire to look through telescopes and to buy a telescope and eventually made my own telescope and
Gradually became more and more in contact with the astronomical community.
I was good at school.
Where did you go to undergrad school?
Went to the University of Rochester.
And when did you graduate from there?
And what was your major?
Astrophysics.
Did you start out in astrophysics?
I started out in astrophysics.
Why?
Why did I start in astrophysics?
Because with my middle school and high school experience in making my own telescope and reading about astronomy,
I decided that was an area that I wanted to go into.

As a matter of fact, I only applied as an undergraduate to Cornell and to the University of Rochester in New York State because those were the only schools that had undergraduate degrees in astronomy.
Where did you go to grad school and why?
I went to the University of Arizona because I realized that I needed to be at a clear sight where I could get into astronomy.
It had a good national reputation.
It was growing.
I applied to the University of Michigan and to Harvard.
I got accepted at Michigan, didn't get accepted at Harvard, and then Arizona and NASA traineeship and so on.
It was the best decision of my then young life.
Because the University of Arizona, of course, is right across the street from Kitt Peak National Observatory.
So what did you do at Arizona?
At Arizona?
I got interested in x-ray astronomy and optical astronomy and no radio astronomy really.
And gradually did a thesis under Bengt Westerlund using photographic data and photoelectric data on Cepheids and OB associations and the relationship of them.
And when did you get out?
Why did you pick that?
Why did I pick that?
Was it the person or the field?
Person, primarily, I think.
It was the ease with which I was able to work with Dr. Westerlund and his vast experience in the field of observational optical astronomy.
Of course, I was exposed to almost everything there was to be exposed to back in the late 1960s because of our interaction with Kitt Peak National Observatory.
And there were theoreticians around.

You know, I did fairly well at most of my courses, but I found after thinking about what I really wanted to do for three or four months, I decided that I wanted to go into studying Cepheids and OB associations with Bank.
He had lots of, he was an interesting guy.
He had lots of unreduced observational data to work with and was inspirational in helping me decide, you know, what further observations were to be made and so on.
I think that's
Sort of a typical interaction.
It wasn't a question of money, as it is these days, because I was supported by a NASA traineeship.
Was that your first contact with an ASA?
Yes, basically it was.
When did you finish your?
I finished in late 1969.
When you were a grad student at Stuart, did any of the infighting, well, or let's put it this way, Kuiper and Bart Bock were perhaps not the world's greatest friends?
You know, I didn't really get too much feel from that.
I mean, Bock came in 1967 after I'd been there a couple of years.
He was always telling stories about Kuiper and Bach, and I don't know, there was another guy, another Dutchman that came over to the U.S. about the same time as those two, and I can't remember.
I think it was a guy, Peter Vandekamp, was it?
No, but it's in Ray White's obituary at Bach, so we can look at it.
Yeah, yeah, it's kind of neat, yeah.
Did people at Stuart or Kitt Peak look down on planetary work as far as you know?
Did the grad students say, oh, if I can't get in with somebody that does stellar work, I'll have to do planetary?
Was any of that kind of stuff still left when you were there?
I don't think so.
Now that I think of it, yeah.
Being a graduate student at Stuart was an interesting experience because you had a lunar and planetary lab right across the street.
And the people that did planetary science, like Tom Garrels, like Pat Romer,
I can't think of a few more names that were associated with a lunar and planetary observatory.
They were there, yeah, exactly.
And I never got the feeling that this was a secondary science.
There was Bill Hartman, for example.
He was there.
I mean, it was interesting stuff.
It just so happened that
you know, you really do have a difference of opinion as to whether you want to go into planetary science.
I mean, planetary science is almost like geology.
It's close to home.
And at least that was my feeling.
I didn't want to get into planetary science, and I knew other graduate students that really didn't want to get into planetary science.
They were more interested in stars and galaxies.
And that's just sort of a natural, because there were graduate students, as a matter of fact, Ben Zellner,
who's now, I guess he does asteroid work with , there was , there was a few other graduate students.
Planetary science was a real challenge.
It just wasn't something that I wanted to get into.
Where'd you go after you got your degree?
In January of 1970, we packed our bags, put our car on a boat, got on an airplane,
and went to Chile.

I became a staff member at the European Southern Observatory, primarily because Westerland, my thesis advisor six months earlier, had become the director there, and he said, Bob, why don't you come down for a year?
So I said, fine, a year, I'll go anywhere.
Ended up being settled.
What did you work on there in general?
In general, I was a staff astronomer, of course, and I had to assist him.
all the equipment for all the visiting astronomers in terms of Kude spectrographs, Castorine spectrographs, single channel photometers and so on.

And I continued my interest in OB associations and started surveying some of the southern Milky Way in terms of accumulating data that would allow us to then determine whether or not the young blue stars we were detecting were actually members of associations or whether they were just in the field.
And when did you leave there and why?

I left there in May of 1977, and we'd been in Chile seven years, and our daughters were then one and four years, so we decided to come back to the States, and we didn't want our kids growing up Chilean, basically.
And the position I got in the U.S. was as a lecturer at the University of Virginia in Charlottesville.
And I found it very difficult to look for a position from outside the US to get back into the US.
And so I was very grateful to be able to get some kind of temporary position from which I could use as a base to look for a more permanent position.
And that fell into place, unfortunately, upon the death of Nelson Lindbergh.
This is D. Nelson Lindbergh.
D. Nelson Lindbergh, exactly.
And so what was this permanent place?
Well, the position I got was University of Virginia as lecturer.
And I was actually on the staff there for two years.

And at the end of the second year, which would be 1979, in the middle 19s after academic year, 78, 79, I then took up a position at the National Radio Astronomy Observatory, more of an administrative position as assistant to the director with Mark Roberts.
At that point, it was better not to have to move the family than to go to Washington, D.C. or someplace like that.
Why did they pick you?
I was a warm body.
No, Mort Roberts and I got along very well.
I had worked earlier as a summer student at NRAO in 1964 in Green Bank with Mort.
And I was interested in a...
in an administrative position because I had been interviewed.
Actually, I had been offered a job at the National Science Foundation by Bill Howard.
And so I was trying to decide, did I want to leave Charlottesville and move to Washington or what?
And Mort had just taken up position as director at NRAO about six months earlier, and he realized that he needed help.
So for me, it was a new challenge I was happy to move into.
How long did you stay there?
Oh, I was with the NRAO, actually, until just the beginning of this year.
I was in Charlottesville until mid-1988.
So that's 11 years in Charlottesville and an additional four years in Socorro.
At the VLA.
At the VLA, right.
When you first went into the National Radio Astronomy Observatory, did you notice any difference between optical and radio astronomers?
As a matter of fact, I did.
I've always noticed the difference between optical and radio astronomers.
You want to know what that difference is?
Yes, you mean going back to grad school days?
Yeah, basically.
I mean, in grad school, I have to admit that I never really came across that many radio astronomers.
Oh, there was Frank Lowe, and there was the odd, I mean... Rare.
The rare radio astronomer that would come through.
We did have one radio astronomer on the staff
one official quote-unquote radio astronomer on the staff at the University of Arizona, and that was Andrei Paholchek.
And he taught the course in radio astronomy, and I found radio astronomy to be much, much greater, much more intensity in real physics.
That is, radio astronomers seem much more solidly based and solidly ground, if you will, in...
in techniques and a theory of physics.
The frustration, of course, with the radio astronomers, I found, of course, was that they didn't have any good angular resolution.
They had instrumentation that they had to be extremely careful with.
It seemed to me that radio astronomers knew a lot more about the inner workings of the computer than optical.
I can't take that back.
Optical astronomers generally knew a lot about their spectrographs.
their polarimeters and photometers, because they had to make it work.
Radio astronomers, however, had found the nice technique of relying upon a really high-quality staff of radio engineers and computer scientists.
And so the actual astronomers really didn't know that much about the black boxes they were using, but the people that did made everything work exceedingly well.
And at the NRIO, I noticed that most of the radio astronomers
that I dealt with hardly ever would, they sort of looked down upon optical astronomy.
They didn't care really what a spectral type was or what constellation or anything like that.
They were really retooled physicists or retooled ham radio operators more than anything.
Whereas optical astronomers tended to be types that got excited about astronomy from hands-on
observing experiences when they were either in high school or college.
And there was a rare optical astronomer who got into optical astronomy because they were good in physics and they were good in theory and then got pushed into optical astronomy.
But in general, I thought the problems that radio astronomers were asking and were able to answer were a lot more in-depth in physics and global problems than optical astronomers were asking.
Maybe that was naive, but that's my impression.
Okay, so this year, early this year, I guess, you left Socorro, and where did you go?
I left the, actually I left the NRAO, and I left Socorro both at the same time, and I'm now Executive Director of the Astronomical Society of the Pacific.
And for me it's an ideal position because
You know, I've sort of been a hybrid between optical and radio astronomy.
I've never really put my solid foot down and said, this is my area, and I am pigeonholed forever.
I just really get excited about all problems in astronomy, and I've always been involved with public outreach and public information since coming back to the NRAO.
When I was in Chile, of course, I was working hand in
in glove with all the visiting astronomers.
So I got to see a broad perspective of the type of problems that everybody that came to the observatory was working on.
And then when I came back to the U.S., I was involved with radio astronomy.

So then I got a perspective of what it is to, what it means to be a millimeter wave astronomer or a centimeter wave astronomer or even a long wave astronomer and what the problems of resolution are and
and different wavelength approaches to different problems.
And so I found myself, you know, with quite a large global perspective that I guess I'm really now able to take advantage of in my dealings with the astronomical community.
Why did you make this last jump?
Was it because the opportunity was there?
Basically, it was the opportunity was there.
You know, Andy Fracknoy had been the executive director of the Astronomical Society of the Pacific for the last 14 years or so.
And...
I saw the advertisement in one of the, I think it was the AAS's job newsletter.
I read the description, you know, it must be this, it must be that, and experience of this, experience of that.
I said, you know, this is a job I can do.
I can do all that stuff.
I almost replied to that myself, and that would have been some competition, except that this NASA contract was already looking good.
I see, I see.
We already had word that we got it.
And also, I have to add that it was more or less an opportunity for me to be my own boss, as it were.
It's kind of hard to work year after year after year, sometimes having ideas that your boss doesn't necessarily share, enthusiasm, support, and so on.
And now, in this position, I can sort of make it or break it.
I can pave new ground if I really get enough energy up to do it.
So you've done optical, you've done radio, and now you have...
I have to do everything.
I have to do everything.
Which is one of the reasons I want to interview, because I'm going to start asking you some questions now today.
How important do you think NASA money was to helping astronomy in general, and planetary astronomy in particular, take off?
Well, I don't know where to begin to answer that question, of course.

For NASA, to answer about the importance of NASA money to astronomy in general, I'd say that the educational opportunities that NASA money afforded to people like me, even though I never ended up in planetary astronomy, the research that I did never really affected any of the NASA missions.
It was really invaluable at the time because I was able to go through graduate study with a school without worrying about teaching assistants or outside jobs or what have you.
Of course, I've seen the NASA money and the support that it provided to the, I guess it was the Mount Lemmon 61-inch telescope and all the research work that got done there.
You know, the telescope on Mauna Kea.
There's a NASA telescope there, infrared facility.
There's two.
There's the 88-inch and the IRT.
That's right, that's right.
And I think, in hindsight, I would say NASA probably could have put more money in ground support to some of their missions than they did.
I mean, it's always...
Ground support has always been looked upon by the people in national centers as only funded by the National Science Foundation.
The question has always been raised, for example, how much impact will the space telescope or any of the other NASA-funded
orbiting telescopes have on ground-based facilities?
And should NSF worry about having to fund more ground support and so on?
I mean, you get the idea that I think we've always worried about is the demand for ground support going to overwhelm
the telescopes on the ground once we get all these observations from space.
And I think the answer has been sort of halfway between the real terror and the optimism.
I mean, my opinion has always been that, hey, there's only 24 hours in a day and there's a limited number of astronomers.
And if they're off getting X-ray data, they don't have time to be getting radio data from the ground or optical data from the ground.
There's no doubt that every single space observatory that has returned data has changed the character of the proposals that have been submitted to the ground-based support .
I mean, for example, back in 1983, when IRS data started coming down,

the 12-meter telescope probably had like 40, 50 percent of its proposals for the next three or four years were always mentioning IRS data this and IRS data this and we're following up this from IRS and that from IRS.
Basically, the number of proposals did not overall to the telescope didn't increase.
The character of the proposals changed because researchers were getting data from infrared and now they wanted to
That's exactly parallel in planetary ground-based observing every time a probe goes by.
Exactly.
One question before I forget here, because I skipped the lore on a little bit.
30 years ago, if we'd be in an AAS meeting, there'd just be one AAS meeting.
Everybody would be in here.
Now, you don't see many planetary papers.
You don't see many solar papers.
We've got all these divisions, high energy, astrophysics, solar astronomy, planetary astronomy, historical astronomy.
And some of them have their own specialized journals now.
In addition, in the old days, it was APJ, AJ, and PASB.
Publications of the Astronomical Society of the Pacific.
Do you think these subdivisions of the AAS have been good or bad, or just inevitable?

I think you put the nail on the head when you said inevitable, because the general expansion of the field makes it, I mean, even the American Physical Society just cannot have a general meeting where everybody exchanges information in a worthwhile manner.
on a broad diversity of topics.

I mean, as much as I, in the astronomical side of the Pacific, feel that the public needs to be exposed to a broad range of topics in a general sense, you know, solar astronomy, planetary astronomy, extra-gallactic astronomy, and all the wavelength and so on, and it's good to meld them all into one sort of uniform picture, at the detailed professional level, where you're talking researcher to researcher,
The meetings, especially the division meetings, extremely important that they're talking on the same topics.
You would totally dilute the effort if you were to mix extragalactic types with the division meetings.
The data transmission rate would be very low.
On the other hand, it's also very important, a very important part of these meetings is to have the overall
survey talk, you'll find a very high percentage of the members of the AAS are younger graduate students or people that are in academic positions where they're teaching on all subjects.
And for them to have a broad perspective of what's going on in planetary science or X-ray astronomy or high energy astrophysics or you name it.
In this meeting it seems to be extreme ultraviolet astronomy.
And in other meetings it's been IRAS, and sometimes it's the Ultraviolet Astro Program.

It's essential to have these overviews sort of cycle around all the disciplines in astronomy so that your younger folks or your people that are teaching general courses and so on have a good perspective of the big picture.
chop it up so little that planetary sciences only go to planetary science meetings.
It's not fair.
Do you think planetary astronomy is part of astronomy?
Do I think it's part of astronomy?
That's a good question.
I think it is part of astronomy.
But I'm asking myself, why do I think it's part of astronomy?
We use telescopes.
That's right.
Planetary scientists use telescopes.
Some of them use space probes, however, which are not really telescopes.
It's more like a remote geologist.
You may have too much knowledge to answer, so let me ask you this.
You're the big cheese at the PASP, and you ought to have your finger on the pulse of this.
Do you think the public believes planetary astronomy is part of astronomy?
Oh, yes.
Oh, yes.
There's no doubt about that.
When people ask general questions about astronomy or what draws them into the interest of astronomy overall, one very important part is planetary.
After all, that's what you can show them in a small telescope.
Granted, they're going to ask questions about the Big Bang or search for extraterrestrial intelligence.
Let's not forget that the search for extraterrestrial intelligence is related to planetary systems.

And the more we know about our planetary systems, for example, at the ASP, the questions I get from the press or radio and television stations, they increase enormously during the time when we have a lunar eclipse, a solar eclipse, a close cometary approach, a meteor shower.
I mean, these are things that the public can easily identify because they can easily see them.
So from the public's perspective, planetary astronomy may be the only part of astronomy they ever come in contact with.
You think, you know, we've had 30 years and now we can see details on Jupiter that we never saw, rings around other planets than Saturn, Mars, pictures in the surface.
Do you think that's had any effect on the public?
I mean, has it changed the way they look at things or their interests in planetary astronomy, astronomy and science in general?
Or is it a passing fact?

You know, I think we have to be careful to answer a question like that because I think that the space program in general and also the detailed information that comes from the space probes about other planets in the solar system has made the public almost take things for granted.
I remember when I was in high school or when you were in school,
You know, one space probe, one space launch was a fantastic event.
Nowadays, we have shuttles get set up every month or two, and no big deal.
We don't go through the countdown.
We don't hear anything in the news.
You know, we know they're up there.
We take it for granted that they're doing good stuff.
And another space probe goes by.
I mean, Voyager was a big deal, no doubt about it.
But, you know, does the public get excited about another telescope getting launched?
Astronomers make lots of noise about it.
And the amount of information that comes from that new telescope can be overwhelming.
There's just so much data coming down.
But the public is sort of getting blase about the whole thing and taking things for granted.
Here's a question you don't have to be a planetary astronomer to answer.
But you have to know something about astronomy and the funding end and all that.
and the public interest in.
In 30 years now, we've looked all over the solar system, haven't yet found a trace of present or previous life anywhere except Earth.
In particular, no green men on Mars, not even a bug.
Sure.
Do you think that's had a negative effect on public interest funding or not?
No, I don't think so.
I really don't think so.
Why don't I think so?
That's a good question.
I mean, I think the search is fun.
And the questions always come down from the press or from people that don't know a lot of details about the types of search and so on.
Have you found it?
Part of the problem that the scientist has in communicating science to the public
is related to their desire to know the biggest or the smallest, the most distant or the closest, the oldest or the youngest, or what's the latest discovery.
I mean, they think science is made up of just eureka discoveries, and they don't really understand the scientific curiosity process.
So I think there's an interest, you know, in the public.
If you say that you're looking for extraterrestrial intelligence or you're looking for life in the solar system,
And that's always a motivation to get the public interested.
They're always going to ask you, did you find it?
But part of the challenge of being a scientist is to give the public more appreciation for the fact that it's the hunt that's most important.
It's the thrill of the hunt, and that continues no matter what you find.
You open more unanswered doors than you do, you know, you always ask more questions after you've made an experiment than you answer.
It's just amazing.
Here's a two-part question.
One, do you think astronomers in general have done a good job, or as good a job as they could have been, in selling themselves to the public and to the Congress?

And then I'm going to be specific and say, I believe that the radio astronomers have always done their infighting behind closed doors, spilled the blood there, and come out charging with a unified front, whereas the optical astronomers do all their internecine strife on the stage.
So Perot, Kahn, what do you think?

Getting astronomers, or getting scientists in general, but the scientists I know best are astronomers, and getting astronomers to be forthright and to participate in public outreach programs is a mixed bag.
There's about, I would say, like 10% of the astronomers on the staff of major research facilities that are really willing to
be science for judges or to give tours to observatories and so on.
I think it's a lot different when you get to the academic community because their people are constantly dealing with students and the public and so the percentage there probably is much higher.
I think and on that basis I would say astronomers really haven't done a good job but I mean how many astronomers do you need to have out there
One Carl Sagan is worth 10,000 other astronomers.
And so it's kind of hard to answer that question.
Now, related to the question of optical versus radio, I think you have to be very, very careful.
Because radio astronomers have always been really totally dependent very soon after the beginning of radio astronomy.
Radio astronomy actually began in the 1930s and really wasn't going full force until the 1950s after the war.
And very soon thereafter was the creation of national observatories.
So radio astronomers have always, not always, but for the most part, have been using national facilities.
You just know they cannot spend the money at a local university to build an instrument big enough, so it's been national facilities.
And it's a much smaller population of scientists, let's say probably between 10% and 20% of the number of optical astronomers.
And so the people to do the fighting are fewer.
The efficiency of getting telescope time for the members of the community because of the existence of large national centers like Arecibo and NRAO and so on,
and some major university facilities like Owens Valley and so on.
It's much more successful for radio astronomers to get telescope time.
Optical astronomers, on the other hand, they come from a different community at the outset.
Historically, they grew up in large private telescopes like Lick and Mount Palomar and so on.
And so they were in-house type astronomers.
And only over the course of the last three decades, so to speak, since the NSF was founded, have you gotten astronomers spread out far and wide at small schools and large schools and everywhere.
And they don't have their own telescopes.
And so there's the in-group, the people that have their own private, as it were, major facility, University of Texas, Caltech,
Those big places, Arizona and so on, and those people are sort of the upper cream, the best scientists there always have lots of telescope time.
And you've got the other community out there fighting for telescope time because they don't have their own telescopes that are there.
It seems to be a much, for one thing it's a much larger community, I'd like to say before probably a factor of 10 higher.
and there's not enough national facility telescope time to go around for this large mass of scientists that are groping for time.

So they tend probably, you know, when it comes right down to it, it's easy to say, you know, you iron your difficulties out in private, but there's always somebody that walks away feeling hurt whenever you have a discussion about whether planetary science is better than,
extragalactic or ultraviolet is better than x-ray and so on.
Somebody...
In that connection, planetary astronomy is really half and half.
It shares some characteristics with both.
But what I'm thinking of, for example, a 10-year
recommendation reports come together.
The radio astronomers seem to pick one thing and stick with it.
Planetary astronomers pick one thing and stick with it.
And the stellar and galactic and extra-galactic optical astronomers keep right on fighting even after it comes out.
It seems like it.
It always seems that way.
It does seem that way.
But I can tell you that there's plenty of hurt people in the radio community, too.
Although they came together and endorsed VLBA,
back in the early 80s.
And lo and behold, the darn thing is constructed now because it was a project that was ready to go when the funding became available.
There are also a lot of hurt people in the radio community that were hoping for a 25-millimeter wave dish.
It never happened.
And the NRAO is ready to go with a millimeter array.
I don't know if it'll ever happen.
And gradually the astronomers at some of the major universities have started to build their own millimeter array.
Millimeter astronomers have basically felt like they've been left off.
And it's an extremely powerful field.

Lately, a lot of astronomers, and we're talking optical, radio, planetary, stellar, have been getting a lot of publicity and evidently some money off of projects that get a lot of public play, like search for extraterrestrial intelligence, killer asteroids, search for other solar systems, ozone holes in the Earth's atmosphere.
Do you think they're overdoing that or not?
I think the public is extremely interested in these type of
projects, and it's good that they get press.

I think astronomers have to be careful to spread the press out to, and I think the AAS does a real good job, and Steve Moran in the press office, in getting the press interested in other ongoing critical issues in astronomy.
You have to remember that some of those topics in modern astronomy are pretty esoteric and hard to describe to the public, so killer asteroids and

SETI and all those you know planetary stuff that's when one respect planetary science has an advantage it's easier to communicate the problem to the public i don't think we can i don't think we can really overdo communicating the public however and what's good for planetary scientists
in the short run because their project is described well to the press.
It's good for astronomers in general.
Whether it's planetary, radio, or optical, I think probably all in the same bathtub.
I mean, all in the same boat.
And is the boat sailing along nicely?
Is it dead in the water?
Or is it sinking in general as far as, say, funding goes and stuff like that?
Well, I don't know.
I have to be careful.
Not necessarily just funding, because we know that's dead in the water.
But what do you think?
Use your crystal ball.
I mean, I've always felt that we tend to get too greedy.
We tend to get a major facility and then milk it to death for data.
And we're never satisfied.
There's another facility we just have to have, another facility we just have to have.
And admittedly, it is a complex area because you always need more resolution.
You always need a different wavelength coverage.
And the problems nowadays are not simply focused in what you can get out of the ultraviolet data or what you can get out of the infrared data.
You have to put the whole thing together in one big multi-wavelength picture.
And astronomers know you need 20 telescopes and not just one.
And Congress wonders, well, jeez, I just gave you one.
Why do you need another one?
But is the situation healthy?
I think that in terms of our ability to do research, let's say the ability to gather the data that we need, the situation is extremely healthy.
The question on an individual basis, for an individual, can an individual exist at a university or make a career, you know, there's a threat there.
There's a threat there because the funding, the instruments are there, the data is there for the best people.
The question is what about the middle pack?
Is there enough funding to attract
the brightest students into the field, to keep them into the field, and so on.
And I think the situation there is of great concern.
The number of PhDs that are generated is like a factor of three or four at least, more than the number of real jobs.
And that's a concern.
That's not healthy in the long term.
On the other hand, should there be a continuous growth in the number of PhDs that are created in a field like astronomy, I think we have to reach a steady state.
Otherwise, there won't be any archaeologists left, and there won't be any new farmers, and so on.
I think one indicator of public interest and the public taxpayer's willingness to support, give money to astronomy,
Are the fortunes of the Astronomical Society of the Pacific, how are those doing now?
Well, the Astronomical Society of the Pacific has always had great success in its programs, primarily because it addresses issues in education.
There's a vast pool of teachers out there that need help.
and information on astronomy and the way to teach it to kids and so on.
Teachers that have not had any formal training themselves and sometimes not even formal training in science.

The ASP has extremely successful summer meetings that have just grown by leaps and bounds in communicating science in a very popular way and also addressing some professional scientific topics as well as teacher workshops and so on.
The problem that the ASB has is one that most nonprofit societies face at one time or another, and that's the bottom line in terms of getting the funds it requires just to keep operating.
I mean, it's a small society.
Its historical base is regional.
It's so broad that it has been hard in the recent past to actually attract funds, I guess, basically, in terms of there's no real strong corporate support.
Those are some of the goals that I have in getting strong corporate support and getting the programs underwritten
by funding agencies, people that are interested in education, and getting more professional involvement in the society.
Some people join the society, and after a year or two, they realize that they come to the conclusion that they're not getting enough out of society to continue being members.
And my answer to them is, hey, listen, the society is made up of you.
You maybe don't have enough time to go out and talk to your local school classes or to give a public lecture and so on.
But as a scientist, as an astronomer, you should give some strong support and backing to those people in the scientific community
who are willing to do the outreach programs that you basically should be morally obligated to support because you're getting support from the public.
And so you've got to give something back.
Some people just don't like to do that.
So why not join the society and let the society do it for them and speak strongly with one voice?
So the society is in a great state of change right now in terms of expansion, in terms of seeking
funding support, and in terms of the type of programs we want to get into, I have no doubt that we'll succeed in all this.
This doesn't have anything to do with the history of planetary astronomy, but I've got to ask you.
The very name, Astronaut of the Pacific, implies regional.
We don't want to be just regional anymore.
I'm thinking of changing the name.
That question was put to me originally when I got interested in society.
I looked at it and I said, yeah, you're right.
The name is a detriment when somebody back in Georgia
goes to their dean and says they're going to publish a paper in the PASP.
He says, why the PASP?
Why not the PASA?
If there's such a journal.
Or if you go to the University of Florida and say you want to have a meeting of the ASP in Florida, they're going to say, who's the ASP?
But
You have to remember the society is a real venerable society.
It's been around for over 100 years.
There's a very strong following here on the West Coast and in several of the states in the U.S. And we even have members from 70 foreign countries.
There are plenty of other organizations that exist with strange names.
It just makes it a little bit more of a challenge, a little more of a challenge
challenge to do our I don't really feel that it's a time to upset the apple cart by making a name change.
A new director and a new name change?
No, no, no.
We'll exist with our own name, with our old name.
